title: Right Internuclear Ophthalmoplegia following a Stroke
chief_complaint: I am frustrated with my sense of balance and my inability to move my head rapidly or process complex visual environments. I feel a spinning sensation at times where the room moves counterclockwise, and I have trouble using power tools at my construction job.

problem_summary.onset: Acute onset 11 months prior following a right pontine angle stroke.
problem_summary.course: Initial severe symptoms (diplopia, nausea) improved, but imbalance and visual processing issues persisted.
problem_summary.laterality: Bilateral findings with right-sided central pathology (INO) and left-sided caloric weakness.
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Dizziness, diplopia (resolved to minor difficulty), spinning sensation, difficulty moving eyes rapidly.
problem_summary.functional_impact: Unable to adequately perform job in construction; difficulty using machinery/power tools; requires concentration for tasks.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Return to work and normal daily activities.

history.present_illness: Admitted 11 months prior for right pontine angle stroke with symptoms of imbalance, dizziness, diplopia, nausea, and vomiting. Neuro-ophthalmology 1 month post-stroke diagnosed Right Internuclear Ophthalmoplegia (INO) and skew deviation. Diplopia improved significantly by 2 months post-stroke, but imbalance persists.
history.otologic_history: Reports spinning sensation (counterclockwise). Difficulty moving eyes rapidly.
history.noise_exposure_history: Construction worker (implied noise exposure, though not explicitly detailed in history).

tests.name: cVEMP
tests.key_findings: Responses were absent in both ears.

tests.name: Video-oculography (Gaze)
tests.key_findings: 4Â°/s leftward beating gaze nystagmus present for leftward gaze without fixation in the left (abducting) eye only.

numeric_results.nystagmus_velocity: 4 deg/sec (left eye, left gaze, no fixation)

tests.name: Video-oculography (Saccades)
tests.key_findings: Disconjugate saccades consistent with Right INO. Lag noted in the right (adducting) eye when moving leftward.

tests.name: Bithermal Caloric Irrigation
tests.key_findings: Significant left reduced vestibular response. No spontaneous nystagmus prior to irrigation.

overall_audiologic_summary: The evaluation identifies central vestibular pathology consistent with the history of a right pontine stroke. Key findings include a persistent Right Internuclear Ophthalmoplegia (INO) evidenced by disconjugate saccades (lag in right eye adduction) and gaze-evoked nystagmus in the left eye. Additionally, there is a 48% left reduced vestibular response on caloric testing, which may represent a peripheral component or central pathway involvement. cVEMPs are absent bilaterally.
counseling_points: Your persistent imbalance is caused by a coordination problem between your eyes (the INO) and a weakness in the balance system on the left side.
The 'lag' in your right eye movement causes visual distortion when you move your head quickly, which explains your difficulty with power tools and busy environments.
Continue physical activities as much as possible, but be very cautious in complex visual environments (like crowded stores).
When walking or working, try to move your head more slowly to allow your eyes to track together effectively.
notes_for_actor: Portray a construction worker who is frustrated by the loss of physical capability.
You do not have obvious double vision (diplopia) right now, but you feel 'off' when looking around quickly.
Mention that using power tools feels unsafe because you have to concentrate too hard to see clearly.
